narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: i gained a pretty basic understanding of climate change and the science behind it
Learned about climate change.
Topics surrounding so many climate science modules: the oceans, atmosphere, pollutants, chemical cycles, ocean circulation, climate, weather, environmental technologies, so so much!

I learned so much about the science of the climate and of climate change! Especially in a time in which science is so highly debated, I think it's important for everyone to have some basic scientific literacy in contentious topics. Before taking this class, the only thing I could say to refute claims that climate change isn't real was "97% of scientists agree." Now I know all about climate models and why the wind blows like it does and what's making the sea levels rise. This is a science credit that you'll actually use in your daily life if you're not a STEM major.

I learned a great deal about the science behind anthropogenic climate change and its socioeconomic and cultural impacts. I learned about some of the landmark policy decisions, past and current, that shape our mitigation of the climate change crisis.
This was a good introductory EPS class. I learned about the basics of the Earth's climate, and how it is being effected by greenhouse gas emissions.

This class provided an excellent survey of global climate change. I learned the historical context critical for understanding the contemporary changes. This class also provided an overview of some of the specific scientific processes at play, without drowning lectures in obscure details. We covered the recent history of addressing climate change and covered current events at the beginning of each class.
The ability to explain the planetary science of climate change in clear language to a non-technical audience.

A deeper understanding of the problems that our world faces, both in combating climate change and surviving it.

Also, it teaches you how to understand scientific papers (a good skill, even if you're a humanities-centered student).

This class was extremely robust in an extremely vital way. A range of topics were covered, all from a very beginner perspective so that it was friendly to people who weren't extremely well-versed in the exact science behind climate change. I feel very comfortable explaining to other people what I learned in this class.
I understand Climate Change better. I practiced how to read scientific sources and then write them in a format that the general public can understand.
Surveys the important scientific and environmental topics necessary to understand the science behind climate change.
Everything about climate
I learned an overview of climate issues relating to wildfires, agriculture, the oceans, and more

The course was a great introduction to the planetary sciences generally. It explained the basic workings of the Earth and related them directly to climate and how it can change thereafter. I now feel confident explaining often talked about climate phenomena and how they are linked to change. Moreover, the policy aspect taught me lots about how politics interact with this science.

A greater understanding of the scientific processes behind climate change. Some cool and really interesting information on current mitigation and adaptation strategies. Rebuttals and strong arguments to climate deniers.
How to write fast because the lectures are really fast and they test you on specific details.
Useful introduction to the vocabulary and science literacy skills required to make your own judgements/evaluations about day-to-day climate news. Worth taking.
Broad understanding of Climate Sciences.

You learn the basics of climate change science, like the movement and transfer of resources (ex: water, salt, carbon) and various ways humans are influenced by climate change (think farming and resource extraction).
Principles of meteorology, as well as the past, present, and future implications of climate change.
I learned more about the state of our world now in the midst of the climate crisis, and some scientific practical steps that governments and people can take to change these circumstances.

I learned a breadth of information about the different spheres of the environment that impact and have the potential to impact global temperatures. I also learned about international efforts/policy that contribute to the global knowledge about climate. The biggest insight I gained was that many climate threats are hypothetical due to limited research. The scientific community has ongoing debates on attribution and impact scale.
Broad overview of climate science in a low-stakes way.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: mary louise is very passionate about her work and wants us to learn. she does experiments to keep us engaged and teaches at a pace we can all understand

weakness: noah. noah is rude, condescending, and teaches with the goal of making you feel dumb. he consistently tries to prove to us that he is smarter than us and he should be because he is the professor and we are students! hated every class that he taught.
more structure, better notes and slides and a more specific framework. at present, everything blends into one.

Strengths: covered a lot of topic in an easy to understand way, the weekly writing assignments were also a great way to practice a bit of academic writing without being overwhelming and engaging with content outside of class. 

Weaknesses: the exams DO have trick questions, and they weigh a lot of the grade, I don't feel like overall grade in the class represents my understanding of the content.

The course and course material were great! I learned a lot about climate change, and the assignments all felt worthwhile. Both the instructors were pretty nice and very knowledgeable. I can't think of any major weaknesses.

Strengths: The weekly writing assignments. I feel like that was where I learned the most about the topic, and it was nice having a bunch of low-pressure, fairly straight forward assignments take up such a large chunk of our grade. Definitely took the pressure off a little bit for the two exams. 

Weaknesses: I didn't love that the exams were multiple choice and kind of nit picky. I think the students that went every day to the lecture would have been better served at displaying their knowledge through more of the written, short answer questions and less questions asking, for example, what degrees of celcius a specific volcanic eruption lowered the earth's temperature. At that point, it's luck if you remember the exact number.

I thought that Noah's slides were sometimes unclear. If they had more text it would have been helpful. Other than that, I thought the course was excellent. Both professors were super invested in the subject material (which makes sense, since climate change is an existential crisis).

Strengths: This class instills students with a terrific overview of climate history and contemporary solutions. I appreciated how this class engaged by STEM and non-STEM majors, emphasizing the relevance of course material on our present and future lives. 

Weaknesses: Some of the lecture slides are a bit convoluted. Midterm and exam questions nitpicked random statistics from lecture that had not been key concepts from the semester.
This course is incredibly unorganized and would benefit from slides that are more concise or perhaps materials that can supplement the slides to help student learning.

This course could be structured much better. TF grading is very inconsistent throughout the class papers with some grading extremely harsh. None of the class slides have any words on them so without attending lecture (and even then) there is no way to go back and review concepts you don't understand. The professors speed run through complicated topics trying to cram lots of information in a 1 hour 50 minute class but neither take the time to slowly unpack the concepts. The professors tell you there are no trick questions on the exams but this is not true, some questions are oddly specific and barely touched on throughout lectures which is unfortunate given the exams are a huge chunk of your grade.

Strengths: breaking down key climate concepts into the science and policy influences.
Weaknesses: the dual-taught design meant class content could at times be better organised.

Having two professors who ran on different schedules made some weeks fairly awkward, as the assignments wouldn't match up with the lectures, or the lectures were given out of order.

Beyond that, both professors were incredibly engaging, and just lacked a class that was willing to engage with them back.

I think a major weakness is the way the exam was written. A lot of the questions required memorization, which I do not think is an accurate measure of the way someone has learned material. And a lot of the time it was the most obscure arbitrary information (like a date or specific number of tons) that was said once in class, but it is ok to be tested on, because it was said in class. This is unfair. 
Other than that, the material was engaging and I enjoyed coming to class twice a week.
Strengths: accessible for students with any background and interests.

Honestly I learned a lot more about climate change than I thought it would. This course covers an array of topics but is taught in a way that you leave with the biggest takeaways. It can be hard to adjust to two different teaching styles but taking notes and looking back on the slides is very helpful.

Strengths: Mary Louise's lectures, Noah's assignments, weekly assignments were usually very manageable and at least somewhat interesting
Weaknesses: Noah's lectures, because the course is co-taught the assignments were sometimes out-of-synch with the lectures and some topics were covered twice, lectures in general could be kind of boring and tough to sit through
Test are direct correlation to slides. Assignments take 1-2 hrs

The professors are very knowledgable about their specific fields but the course lacks a clear direction. The topics weren't presented in a cohesive way. Also, every few weeks, the professors would switch which meant students had to keep adjusting to the different teaching styles. I think that the concepts in the course could be rearranged so that they build on top of one another. Also, the professors could communicate more about the topics that they were covering because some things were repeated.

I appreciated that this course covered so many topics in climate change, but it often felt disjointed and random, lacking continuity between lectures. Additionally, I found many lectures to be repetitive of the same very simple, basic concepts, such as climate change disproportionately affects those who did not cause it. While this is extremely important to be aware of, I felt that our time could have been spent learning more rather than repeating this.

The grading of the course was very relaxed and TAs proved useful if you needed support throughout. However, the two lecturers instruct very differently, not necessarily in a bad way, but it felt that sometimes communication between them wasn't clear. Moreover, at times the 75 minute lecture dragged out a lot but if you keep attentive, this course is engaging. That being said, I did enjoy having the different perspectives from the 2 instructors.

I enjoyed how the course both had a very contemporary outlook with a focus on the COP conference, whilst giving a wider historical perspective and teaching us about historical phenomenon such as the Younger Dryas.

Strengths: lecture class; professors are nice and care about the topic. Weaknesses: boring if you aren't interested in the topic and confusing at times when you do not already know some of the lingo around climate change.
Good introductory-level course, imparted important concepts with a not-TOO-heavy workload.
Would have enjoyed a touch deeper understanding of the science. Maybe a pset would;ve been nice??

strengths: the earth science portions
weaknesses: the generalizations and overarching statistics without a deeper meaning seemed like it wasn't worth the time

Despite what the instructors said, the exams were full of trick questions and questions that focused on minute details rather than larger picture things. Grading on the reading responses was subjective. I liked it when we talked about the political and social implications of climate change.

Strengths: good spread of topics, engaging at times
Weaknesses: some concepts required more STEM background than others to fully understand, making some students more confused than others. lectures were sometimes also very repetitive, especially when talking about the effects of climate change.
The assignments were graded very harshly.
Great teaching and engaging professors, but sometimes challenging assignments.

Strengths were Mary Louise she was a great and patient instructor and honestly all the slides for the entire semester were really easy to follow and very beautiful which honestly is not common in stem classes I've taken so far. Weaknesses are the homework assignments which feel like busy work and don't really seem to give much insight into what would end up on exams. It was also fairly difficult to meet people int he class or get prompt help if you had questions about the homework.

Strengths: breadth of information, live experiments, very different homework assignments, authentic professors
Weaknesses: organization, not very resourceful (considering that the majority of class learning is in lecture, they often forget to release the slides. they also don't do study guides or potential test questions.)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: it is not an easy science credit because the grading is shitty and not transparent but it is good bc the exams are curved and pretty much high school level questions that are like are the winds blowing east to west or west to east.
good science gut, but you learn nothing new
Yes. It's good to get a deeper understanding of climate change and actually know your facts.

A good science credit especially if you don't know much about climate change because you'll receive a critical foundation. However, take good notes to study for the exams because they are not very easy!

Yes, especially if you need to knock out your science credit! I have a much greater understanding of how both weather and climate work from taking this class, and I feel like I've gained knowledge that will be useful to me on a daily basis. (That's the best you can hope for when you're a non-STEM major taking a science class.) It's not a total gutthe exams are fair but not easybut it's not too difficult either. The workload is pretty low, and if you have a good science intuition you'll understand the content easily. (If you're like me and you don't, taking the class with a friend will help a lot!) Taking this class was definitely worthwhile.
I definitely would recommend the course, especially for students less well-versed in the sciences. This course was a fairly straight-forward way to learn about a really important topic.
I would recommend it. It is a good science class for non-STEM majors, but it also covers a very interesting topic. Everyone should understand the dangers of climate change.
This is a terrific class for non-STEM majors to fulfill their science credit. As long as you go to class, the teachers explain all concepts clearly that make keeping pace pretty easy.
No, I would not. The exams have random questions and the slides are not organized. Id you cant learn by simply listening to the professors talk, its not the course for you.
No

Yes - if you are an EVST major, interested in the environment, or just want to be able to explain what is happening in the world and why to a non-technical audience, this course will give you the confidence to do so.

Take it! It gives you a great grounding in the challenges we face in the future on a warming planet -- stuff YOU SHOULD KNOW.

Also, science credit without a lab!
Yes, the material taught in this class is very important and I think everyone needs to know it.
I would! If you want to acquire a basic understanding of climate change, through a course that is not too advanced but still teaches you some new stuff, this is a good option. :)
Yes!!! Take this, especially if you need a science credit!

It's a great course if you need an SC credit, coming from a humanities major. Assignments were writing-based, and quite easy to do very well on. Both exams were not difficult whatsoever, as long as you attended lectures and studied. The course is especially manageable if you took APES in high school or equivalent, even if not, great course for an SC credit or someone who needs it for a major. It's also nice because the content of the course is actually relevant to life.

I may recommend this course to a student who lacks all knowledge about climate change. However, I do not think much would be learned by a student who already has a basic understanding of the climate and keeps up to date on the news.

If you need a science credit, this course is great even if you don't have a strong background in high-school science. I feel that if you know about climate change or are a science major, this course might feel too basic though. Regardless though, if you want to know more about climate change, this is a great place to start.

I would recommend it to everyone. It has equipped me with knowledge that is very useful and I frequently draw into conversation. It is also an extremely important subject, and the teachers are very knowledgable whilst also being impactful scientists in their own right!
Only if you want to major in something related to environmental issues. Do not take this class thinking it's a gut, coming from a humanities major.
Yes. Good way to build science-literacy in climate science (reading journal articles, practicing science communication with the writing assignments, etc.), even for STEM majors.
Yes.
Yes! Mary Louise is a sweetheart and a lovely teacher. The work is super doable and you learn a lot.
Yes, especially if you're interested in majoring in some kind of earth science.
Yes

I thought it was a great science credit if you're willing to put in the work. Assignments are tough to handle if you're not used to reading scientific papers. I have already found much of what I've learned to be useful in the real world.

If you're interested in climate change already I think this is a great course to actually dive into the basics of it all; if you are someone looking for science credit, just note that it is only easily manageable course if you put in the work to consistently go to lectures (there is not a lot of outside help in terms of TFs or instructors I felt).

Yes if you have a decent background in environmental science or climate science, it will be pretty smooth sailing and you might learn about some interesting case studies. If not, it might be difficult since they do not cover science based concepts in depth, and the slides are mostly pictures, so you have to rely on the way the professors explain the material. Sometimes they both explain the same concept differently which may impact your ability to understand
Yes, for a low-stress SC credit that gets across really essential knowledge.
Yes, this is a really great course if you are learning about the science behind climate change and get a good introduction to the EPS major.
